0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Local anesthesia: apply TOPICALLY for 3-7 seconds from distance of 3-9 inches until skin just begins to turn white
  • Myofascial pain: use spray and stretch technique; from distance of 12-18 inches, apply TOPICALLY to skin at acute angle to lessen the shock of impact; direct spray in parallel sweeps 1.5-2 cm apart at the rate of approximately 4 inches/sec; continue until entire muscle has been covered

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• contains a chemical known to State of California to cause cancer
  • known liver and kidney toxin, avoid long-term exposure
  • avoid inhalation
  • flammable; do not use in the presence of open flame or electrical cautery equipment
  • when used to produce local freezing of tissues, protect adjacent skin with petrolatum

sub.title: Pregnancy Category
sub.mono: Fetal risk cannot be ruled out. (TH)

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Ethyl chloride is a topical anesthetic agent for controlling pain. It is a skin refrigerant to relieve minor injuries and a counterirritant to manage myofascial pain, restricted motion and muscle tension.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Topical
  • spray affected area until skin turns white; do not frost the skin
  • (myofascial pain) cover patient's eyes, nose, and mouth if spraying near face; spray from a distance of 12 to 18 inches, directing spray in parallel sweeps from the muscle attachment over the trigger point, through and over the reference zone until entire muscle is covered; passively stretch muscle during application and apply moist heat for 10 to 15 min following treatment

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• adequate local anesthesia
  • numbness
  • renal and hepatic function with long-term exposure

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Freezing may occasionally alter skin pigmentation.
  • Patient should apply topical spray to affected area until skin begins to turn white. Tell patient not to frost the skin.
